intro: Corydalis giraldii, commonly known as the Sierra larkspur, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Fumariaceae family and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and clusters of small, spurred flowers. The plant typically grows in alpine and subalpine meadows, preferring well-drained soils and full sun. Its flowers are usually blue to violet in color, and it blooms in late spring to early summer. Corydalis giraldii is often found in rocky or gravelly habitats and is adapted to the harsh conditions of its mountainous environment.
